stream_context.summary: Kaze continued polishing the Wild West/train–saloon level (later named “Grand Sand Badland”), focusing on interactive saloon doors and gameplay readability (a “3-2-1” quickdraw countdown). Mid-stream, work shifted into engine-side audio: implementing efficient per-sound pitch control (used to deepen Boshi/Yoshi voice lines), cleaning duplicated vanilla/dead audio code, and extending dialogue text boxes to specify pitch. He also implemented the bartender’s hat gag so it grows as the player collects stars, and discussed memory limits, asset improvements from Biobak, and upcoming course plans (Course 14: a space arcade).
stream_context.significance_reason: The stream includes an engine-level audio upgrade (per-sound pitch + dialogue-controlled pitch) that unlocks character voice direction going forward, plus a major level-polish task being checked off (functional saloon doors) and a new recurring level gag system (bartender hat growth per star).

findings.summary: Kaze described his approach to feedback: he encourages critiques but tries to evaluate them objectively rather than defensively, sometimes changing decisions if the criticism holds up.
findings.quote: Always look at criticism very objectively and unemotionally.

findings.summary: For the Wild West quickdraw/shootout encounter, Kaze agreed the fail/transition timing felt too fast and implemented a visible “3-2-1” countdown to improve player readability and fairness.
Kaze noted a known Fast64 issue where render-mode state can “bleed” between objects/materials, which he suspected was causing odd bar/texture behavior in the scene.

To add a Chain Chomp to the Wild West level, Kaze planned to move the Chain Chomp and Wiggler mempool allocations into an object-specific bank, implying object memory limits are now a design constraint for this course.

Kaze said the Wild West course is still missing several polish items: train track placement (not floating), moving train wheels, smoke/VFX and sound for the train, signage, remaining 3D modeling, and finalizing star names.
Kaze briefly described a recurring stress/health pattern: feeling awful before stream, then feeling fine once he starts working, framing it as pressure-related.
Kaze confirmed the level name direction: “Grand Sand Badland” is likely the final name (after some back-and-forth over wording).

Based on feedback (notably Lilaa’s), Kaze adjusted the saloon door proportions (making the doorway/doors smaller) and added the idea of using an icon/symbol on the doors to communicate interaction rules (kick vs ground pound).

Kaze showcased Biobak’s recent visual pass on Course 11, emphasizing how improved texture/combiner work made a previously flat container prop look more weathered and deep, signaling an ongoing art-quality leap as Biobak reworks that course.
Kaze stated he avoids self-inserts in his games, calling them “cringe,” and suggested viewers who want more of him can watch the streams instead.
findings.quote: I think self-inserts is a little cringe.

findings.summary: Kaze debugged the saloon door swing logic: the core error was using the object’s face angle instead of the angle-to-Mario when computing swing direction (compounded by s16 angle wraparound). After switching to angle-to-Mario and tuning rotation/velocity, the doors behaved correctly enough to mark the task as done.

Kaze implemented a new audio-engine capability to pitch individual sound effects efficiently (“almost free” unless actively used), then used it to lower Boshi/Yoshi voice pitch. He removed/disabled an older “sound bank pitch” approach he considered inefficient and confusing, and cleaned up duplicated audio code, celebrating small instruction-count savings alongside maintainability.
findings.quote: Every time you program something, you want it to be free of cost if you're not using that part of code.

findings.summary: Because pitched voices need to be controlled by dialogue, Kaze extended the dialogue/textbox system so dialogue entries can specify pitch values, enabling character-specific vocal direction tied to exact lines (not just global sound hacks).

Kaze implemented the bartender Koopa’s hat gag to grow as the player collects stars in the course (choosing “per star collected” rather than “per act”), explicitly to reinforce a sense of progression/story in the level.
Kaze mentioned potential future performance improvements: Sauraen is working on making F3DEX (F3DEX3) less RSP-intensive, which Kaze hopes will reduce RTYI’s current RSP bottleneck.

biobak.summary: Biobak is actively reworking Course 11’s visuals and delivered improved texture/combiner work (example: a container prop that now reads as weathered with added depth), and he discussed custom music ideas for the Wild West area.

zeina.summary: Kaze noted Zeina is producing textures for some of the signage/scene elements that are not yet present, implying remaining art dependencies for the Wild West course.

findings.summary: Lilaa pushed for clearer timing/readability in the quickdraw shootout (more time before “fire,” plus indicators), which directly led to Kaze implementing a “3-2-1” countdown.
Lilaa’s feedback also steered saloon-door proportions (smaller opening/doors) to make them read more like proper saloon doors and be easier to model/fit in the doorway.
Kaze referenced Sauraen’s ongoing work to reduce RSP cost in the rendering microcode (F3DEX3), which is positioned as a potential solution to RTYI being RSP-bottlenecked.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Always look at criticism very objectively and unemotionally.
memorable_quotes.context: Early-stream philosophy about handling comments/critique without ego, framing it as creator integrity.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Every time you program something, you want it to be free of cost if you're not using that part of code.
memorable_quotes.context: Kaze explains his performance-driven mindset while refactoring audio pitch so unused features don’t tax the N64.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I think self-inserts is a little cringe.
memorable_quotes.context: A clear creative boundary about tone/ego in ROM hacks, contrasting with community trends he dislikes.

key_stories.title: Saloon doors were swinging the wrong way (angle math bug)
key_stories.summary: Kaze tried to make interactive swinging saloon doors, but they repeatedly rotated in the wrong direction depending on how Mario interacted (push vs punch), creating chaotic and inconsistent behavior. The eventual fix was small but revealing: he was using the wrong angle reference in his calculations.
key_stories.challenge: Doors appeared to swing randomly or invert direction, especially when punched; s16 angle wraparound and wrong vectors made debugging confusing.
key_stories.process: He iterated through multiple hypotheses (sign inversion, forward vectors, rebooting, reducing rotation), then re-examined the fundamentals and switched from using the object’s face angle to using the computed angle-to-Mario for swing direction.
key_stories.outcome: Doors became reliable enough to check the task off the list; remaining improvements are aesthetic (shape, texture, symbols) rather than core physics logic.
key_stories.key_quote: It was all because I used face angle instead of angle to Mario.

key_stories.title: Making Boshi sound different required rebuilding pitch control
key_stories.summary: Kaze wanted to deepen Boshi’s voice, but discovered his old implementation path (“sound bank pitch”) was inefficient and confusing. This turned into an engine-level cleanup and a new feature: pitch individual sounds efficiently and drive pitch from dialogue entries.
key_stories.challenge: Existing pitch logic reset oddly (defaulting to 32), duplicated code paths existed, and per-sound pitch risked adding constant CPU cost to every sound effect.
key_stories.process: He removed the old bank-pitch system, implemented an “adjust frequency” approach that only costs work when pitch is used, validated the audible difference by extreme test values, refactored duplicated code, and then extended the dialogue system so specific text boxes can supply pitch values.
key_stories.outcome: Audio engine now supports per-sound pitch; Boshi/Yoshi voices can be lowered reliably, and future characters can have directed vocal identity line-by-line.
key_stories.key_quote: Every time you program something, you want it to be free of cost if you're not using that part of code.

key_stories.title: The bartender’s hat becomes a progression gag tied to stars
key_stories.summary: Kaze added a recurring visual joke: the bartender Koopa’s hat grows as the player progresses. He explicitly chose star-based growth to reinforce that the level has an unfolding “story” rather than disconnected missions.
key_stories.challenge: Decide what game event should drive the gag (acts, stars, ‘criminals jailed’) while keeping it readable and narratively meaningful.
key_stories.process: He counted how many missions actually involve jailing, rejected that metric as inconsistent, then defined a baseline smaller head/hat state and moved it upward by a fixed amount per star collected.
key_stories.outcome: Hat growth now tracks player progression across the course; Kaze labeled it as intentionally stupid but acceptable as an Easter egg most players may only notice briefly.
key_stories.key_quote: I think every time you get a star, because there has to be a story to this level.

key_stories.title: “Save State Yoshi” rap writing session as diegetic anti-cheat humor
key_stories.summary: While reviewing community-submitted dialogue, Kaze curated and edited a set of rhythmic, aggressive ‘Space/Time Yoshi’ rap lines that threaten players for using save states. The segment shows how he balances meme humor with strict formatting constraints and in-universe tone.
key_stories.challenge: Dialogue boxes have strict line/character formatting constraints (he notes it must be exactly 8 units/lines to render correctly), and some submissions felt AI-generated or didn’t scan well.
key_stories.process: He tested and counted syllables/line lengths, rewrote lines for flow, rejected copy-paste/AI vibes, and selected versions that fit the “90s educational rap” vibe while still “going hard.”
key_stories.outcome: A curated set of anti-save-state rap dialogues made it into the build, reinforcing the hack’s playful, self-aware tone and meta-rule enforcement.
key_stories.key_quote: It has to be 8 exactly, otherwise it doesn't render right.

open_questions.topic: Wild West course memory limits and design tradeoffs
open_questions.context: Kaze said the level is ‘kind of out of memory’ and hesitated to add new characters/minigames; he also mentioned moving Chain Chomp/Wiggler allocations into an object-specific bank.
questions: How close to the object/memory limits is this course right now, and what tools do you use to measure that in practice?
What features or characters have you already cut (or expect to cut) specifically because of memory pressure?
Can you walk me through the decision to move specific actors (Wiggler/Chain Chomp) into an object-specific bank—what does that change for the rest of the game?

open_questions.topic: Dialogue-driven voice direction as a design tool
open_questions.context: Kaze extended dialogue entries so text boxes can supply pitch values, enabling character voices to be shaped line-by-line.
questions: Was the goal mainly comedic (Boshi sounding deeper), or is this a broader plan for giving many characters distinct ‘performances’ without recording new VO?
How do you decide what pitch values ‘feel right’ for a character—do you iterate by ear, reference other games, or have a rough musical scale in mind?
Will this system be exposed to collaborators (writers) so they can author pitch as part of dialogue writing, or will it remain a programmer-only tool?

open_questions.topic: Sauraen’s F3DEX3 work and RTYI’s RSP bottleneck
open_questions.context: Kaze stated RTYI is RSP-bottlenecked and hopes Sauraen’s less RSP-intensive microcode work will help.
questions: What symptoms first convinced you RTYI was RSP-bottlenecked (specific scenes, counters, or frame timing patterns)?
What changes are required on your side to integrate Sauraen’s microcode improvements, and what risks could break rendering compatibility?
If the bottleneck eases, what do you want to spend that performance budget on—visual density, effects (train smoke/VFX), more actors, or stability headroom?

open_questions.topic: Course roadmap: ‘Course 14 is a space arcade’
open_questions.context: Kaze revealed Course 14’s theme (space arcade) and said an area already exists, but he’s not fully sure on the next course order.
questions: What does ‘space arcade’ mean mechanically in RTYI—minigames, score attack, physics gimmicks, or a visual theme over standard platforming?
Why did you prototype an area for Course 14 before fully locking the course order—was it inspiration-driven, a technical testbed, or schedule/asset related?
How do you decide when a course is ‘done enough’ to move on, especially when polish lists keep growing (train VFX, star names, signs, etc.)?
